title: Pan-Roasted Pork
subtitle: with Bacon, Brussels Sprout & Sweet Potato Hash
time: Hash, a potato and onion dish, is usually thought of as a breakfast food. But that wasn’t always the case! Named for the French verb “hacher,” or “to chop,” hash has been eaten as an entrée for over 100 years. In 19th Century America, “hash houses” served up their favorite recipes using local ingredients. The dish even appears in cuisines from Scandinavia and Malaysia. In our version, you’ll prepare the hash with crispy bacon, Brussels sprouts and sweet potato as a side for delicious pork cutlets, pan-roasted to perfection.
desc: Hash, a potato and onion dish, is usually thought of as a breakfast food. But that wasn’t always the case! Named for the French verb “hacher,” or “to chop,” hash has been eaten as an entrée for over 100 years. In 19th Century America, “hash houses” served up their favorite recipes using local ingredients. The dish even appears in cuisines from Scandinavia and Malaysia. In our version, you’ll prepare the hash with crispy bacon, Brussels sprouts and sweet potato as a side for delicious pork cutlets, pan-roasted to perfection.

steps.title: Prepare the ingredients:
steps.desc: Wash and dry the fresh produce. Remove the pork from the refrigerator to bring to room temperature. Core and dice the apples. Peel and dice the sweet potatoes. Peel the onion; cut into wedges. Quarter the Brussels sprouts. Pick the mint off the stems. Using a peeler, remove the lemon rind, avoiding the pith; mince to get 2 teaspoons of zest. Quarter the lemon; remove the seeds. In a small bowl, combine the crème fraîche, a pinch of lemon zest and the juice of 2 lemon wedges; season with salt and pepper to taste.

steps.title: Cook the bacon:
steps.desc: Heat a large pan (nonstick, if you have one) on medium-high until hot. Add the bacon and cook, flipping occasionally, 4 to 6 minutes, or until browned and crispy. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate and set aside, leaving any drippings in the pan. Carefully drain off and discard half the drippings.

steps.title: Start the hash:
steps.desc: Heat the pan of reserved bacon drippings on medium-high until hot. Add the sweet potatoes; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 6 to 8 minutes, or until browned and slightly tender.

steps.title: Finish the hash:
steps.desc: Add the onion and Brussels sprouts to the pan; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 3 to 5 minutes, or until slightly softened. Add the apples and half the spice blend. Cook, stirring occasionally, 4 to 6 minutes, or until softened. Add the cooked bacon (crumbling before adding), remaining lemon zest, half the butter and the juice of the remaining lemon wedges. Cook, stirring frequently, 1 to 2 minutes, or until well combined.

steps.title: Cook the pork cutlets:
steps.desc: While the hash cooks, combine the flour and remaining spice blend on a plate. Pat the pork cutlets dry; season with salt and pepper on both sides. Thoroughly coat the seasoned cultets in the flour and spice blend (tapping off any excess). In a medium pan (nonstick, if you have one), heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the coated pork; cook 3 to 4 minutes per side, or until golden brown and cooked through. Transfer to a plate, leaving any browned bits (or fond) in the pan. Set aside.

steps.title: Make the sauce & serve your dish:
steps.desc: Add the remaining butter, 1 tablespoon of lemon crème fraîche, mustard and ¼ cup of water to the pan of reserved fond. Cook on medium, stirring frequently, 15 to 30 seconds. Add the cooked pork (and any juices from the plate); cook, spooning the sauce over top, 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until coated. Remove from heat; season with salt and pepper to taste. Transfer the finished pork and hash to serving dishes. Garnish with the mint (roughly chop before adding). Serve with the sauce and remaining lemon crème fraîche. Enjoy!
